For my entire life, my dad has been my hero. 

Father, you are a man of faith and conviction. You came to America with nothing, and you've given me everything. Thank you. Because of you -- because of your struggle to escape tyranny in Cuba, I've been blessed to understand the preciousness of freedom.

On this Father's Day, I want to thank not only my father, but every father for your dedication to your family and your children.

799 years ago today a band of English barons forced the despotic King John to grant rights to “all the freeman in our kingdom” in a document that became a catalyst for freedom for millions of people around the world.

Magna Carta, as it is known, represented a revolution in governance. Its basic premise—that those in power must obey the law—is the foundation for constitutional liberty. Magna Carta said that a King is subject to the law, that he must abide by the law, that he cannot arbitrarily change the law by his own will, and that he is required to faithfully execute the law.

This hundreds of years old pact between England’s rulers and subjects is particularly meaningful now, as an increasingly imperial President has threatened our own freedoms.  For even though America’s most powerful documents--the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution, and the Bill of Rights--have direct lineage to Magna Carta many of our nation’s leaders no longer seem to respect it.

Today, let us pledge to support leaders who will revere these extraordinary documents and once again honor the rule of law.  It the difference between the success of nations and the fall of nations. History shows us that whenever animating principles of Magna Carta are celebrated freedom thrives; whenever they are disregarded tyranny rises.

Today, on the 799th anniversary of Magna Carta, let us raise up our voices to demand our leaders fulfill the promise Magna Carta made so long ago.

Mom.  The most beautiful word in the English language.  For most of us, the very first words out of our mouths as infants.  "MaMa."  

When actors or athletes win awards (like Kevin Durant just this week), their most passionate thank you is always to Mom.

As a child, Mom can cure everything.  There is no safer place than in your mother's arms.  

My Mom, Eleanor Darragh, is a woman of incredible strength, independence, and compassion.  She fought her father, a difficult man who didn't believe women should be educated, to become the first person in her family to get a college education.  She stood up to him, and graduated from Rice in 1956 with a degree in math.  She went to work at Shell as a computer programmer in the 1950s, blazing an independent path.

Every day, she has been there for me.  She's been a best friend all my life.  She's peaceful, loving, and never judgmental.  She's a prayer warrior, lifting us up every single day.  And she loves unconditionally.  

No image makes me happier than seeing our girls Caroline and Catherine leaping through the air to land in her lap.  Pure joy, for them and her (and me!).

I love you Mom.

And, of course, my radiant wife Heidi, who's Mom to our precious girls.  My Angel.  Heidi is amazing.  She's beautiful, brilliant, passionate, and always unbelievably supportive, no matter how challenging the road we're on.  As I wrote to her in her card this morning, "I need you.  Like Air.  I cannot breathe without you."

Caroline and Catherine adore their Mommy.  Sure, Dad's ok, but he doesn't hold a candle to Mom, who is, bar none, their very best friend.

Today, all of us celebrate the women in our lives who make us who we are.  Today, we celebrate the love that is like oxygen.

Today, all of us say thank you Mom.  We love you.

Ted.

Last night, voters in Texas demonstrated that they want principled conservatives in office. Tea Party activists, Republican women, libertarians, and young people all rallied around insurgent candidates campaigning to listen to the people and get serious about free-market principles and the Constitution. In race after race, the power of the grassroots was overwhelmingly apparent.

Congratulations to every Republican who won the primary last night. Three, in particular, deserve special mention.

Greg Abbott, a close friend and mentor, won a landslide victory in the primary for governor. He's strong, principled, and courageous. For five and a half years, it was an honor to work side-by-side with Abbott. He will make an outstanding governor.

John Cornyn, our senior senator, won his primary as well. John is a friend, and a good man. He's earned considerable respect in the Senate. We have not agreed on everything, but we have agreed on the vast majority of issues. Together, we're a strong and effective team for Texas.

George P. Bush convincingly won his primary for for Land Commissioner. George was one of my very first supporters in our Senate race, and he and his wife Mandi are long-time friends. He's smart, generous, and has a heart for service. George embodies a new generation of leaders for the Republican Party and for Texas.

Congratulations to all three. I'm proud to endorse all three and urge everyone to support the Republican nominees up and down the ballot come November.

Courage and a love of liberty have long been defining characteristics of the Texas spirit. Both were exemplified 178 years ago when fifty-nine delegates convened in Independence Hall at Washington-on-the-Brazos to declare Texas' independence.

Inflamed by General Santa Anna's refusal to abide by the Mexican Constitution of 1824 and inspired by the United States’ first Declaration of Independence, the men produced their own Declaration and resolved ‘that the people of Texas do now constitute a free, Sovereign, and independent republic.’

The same love of ‘life, liberty, and property of the people’ that spurred the Texians at the Alamo and throughout the Revolution still lives in each Texan today. They fought for it. They died for it. We owe it to their sacrifice to carry the torch of freedom for future generations. And we will.

Keep that resolve strong and when anyone threatens our liberties, proudly say, as only a Texan can, ‘come and take it!’

Below are the four conservative Republican Texas Supreme Court Justices running for re-election -- I wholeheartedly endorse all of them. These justices are judicial conservatives, and we can depend on them to uphold the law. I encourage Texas voters to look closely at these races and to make informed choices for the good of our State. Please vote for all four of these candidates and urge your friends, family and neighbors to support them. Thank you!

Jeff Boyd:
Justice Jeff Boyd is a judicial conservative who is deeply rooted in principle. He and I worked side-by-side under Attorney General Greg Abbott, and I’m proud to endorse him.

Jeff Brown:
I’ve known Jeff Brown for 20 years. He’s a judicial conservative who cares deeply about our Constitution and the rule of law. I’m proud to endorse Justice Jeff Brown.

Nathan Hecht:
Nathan Hecht is a strong, principled conservative, with a deep passion for our Constitution. For decades, Chief Justice Hecht has led the judicial conservatives on the Texas Supreme Court, and I’m proud to endorse him.

Phil Johnson:

Today, we celebrate the blessings of a people dedicated to liberty.

Our forefathers fled religious prosecution to pursue the freedom of conscience in the New World, a bedrock principle we must continue to protect.

As the pilgrims in their November 1620 Mayflower Compact, their very first governing framework, wrote: “[We] solemnly and mutually, in the Presence of God and one another, covenant and combine ourselves together into a civil Body Politick, for our better Ordering and Preservation.”

A year later they thanked God for his providence, their first harvest, and a new land of opportunity. It was the nation’s very first Thanksgiving.

Despite the many trials they faced, they expressed gratitude for the opportunity to live freely.

President Calvin Coolidge reminded us nearly a century ago: “We have been a most favored people. We ought to be a most generous people. We have been a most blessed people. We ought to be a most thankful people.”

And, we are.

This Thanksgiving, Heidi and I wish you and your family the very best, and may God continue to bless the Great State of Texas and the United States of America.

On this Hanukkah, I wish our Jewish friends a happy holiday.

The miracle of the oil reminds us of God's provision in times of trouble. The little vessel that kept burning for eight days embodies the hope of a courageous people. Their piety and perseverance through adversity is an inspiration to many. Their steadfastness speaks to their faith in a greater future.

Last week, I had the honor of attending an event celebrating Emma Lazarus, the poet who wrote the words that welcome all to this land of liberty: 'Give me your tired, your poor, Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free, The wretched refuse of your teeming shore. Send these, the homeless, tempest-tossed to me, I lift my lamp beside the golden door!'

We are grateful for the rich history the Jewish culture brings to America and to the world, and I hope you have a blessed Hanukkah season.

With Iran, the administration has gotten it backwards and it is time to reverse course before any further damage is done.

According to the interim agreement regarding Iran’s nuclear program that was reached this weekend in Geneva, not one centrifuge will be destroyed. Not one pound of enriched uranium will leave Iran. Not one American unjustly detained in Iran's notorious prisons will be released. But Iran will start to receive, in a matter of days, $7 billion in relief from international economics sanctions.

All the smiling embraces between diplomats after the interim deal was signed notwithstanding, the Iranian regime remains a brutal and oppressive dictatorship that pursues nuclear weapons for the purpose of dominating the Middle East and threatening America and our allies, notably Israel. President Obama and Secretary Kerry should reconsider their policy of rapprochement with Iran that is dismaying to Jerusalem and encouraging to Tehran. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu predicted this agreement would be a 'very, very bad deal' and has now correctly identified it as an 'historic mistake.' Meanwhile, Iranian President Hassan Rouhani tweeted his satisfaction as the 'breaking down the architecture for sanctions has begun.' The administration has gotten it backwards and it is time to reverse course before any further damage is done.

On the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month of 1918, the fighting between the Allies and Germany ceased. Today, we commemorate that moment by thanking our veterans who have continued the quest to preserve our peace and freedom.

We should all be proud of our country’s long tradition of service. General John J. Pershing eloquently expressed his thanks in a letter to the troops who helped win the “war to end all wars,” that is just as relevant now as it was then.

Pershing wrote, “By willing sacrifice of personal rights; by cheerful endurance of hardship and privation; by vigor, strength and indomitable will, made effective by thorough organization and cordial co-operation, you inspired the war-worn Allies with new life and turned the tide of threatened defeat into overwhelming victory.”

We are so fortunate that throughout history, millions of Americans have come forward to fight tyrants, fascists, communists, and terrorists to keep us free.

Still, we live in a violent world, where the freedoms we enjoy remain exceptional to millions of less fortunate forced to abide by brutal dictators, oppressive regimes, and cultures of intolerance.

The persistent threats of terrorism at home and abroad are reminders of how precious it is to be an American and how fiercely our rights must be protected.

We are blessed to live in a society where men and women continue to fight for our flag. Since the terrorist attacks of 9/11, more than 3 million Americans have volunteered to defend their country, knowing full well the risks they may face. More than 50,000 are serving in Afghanistan right now.

They, like millions of veterans before them, are willingly putting themselves in danger to keep us safe.

Thank you.

President Calvin Coolidge once said, “The nation which forgets its defenders will itself be forgotten.” He was right.

Please join me on this Veterans Day in saying a prayer of thanks for our veterans. And, please find a veteran. Grab their hand. Look them in the eye and tell them, “Thank you for your service.”

We will never be able to express enough thanks for the troops, but they must always know they are treasured.

May God bless the veterans, may God bless all those who continue to protect our country, and may God bless the United States of America.

I commend President Obama for listening to bi-partisan calls for him to seek congressional authority before any possible use of force against Syria. Given that the President did not request an emergency session of Congress, that must mean that he agrees there is no imminent threat requiring the Commander in Chief to act without consulting the representatives of the American people.

I remain concerned that the mission proposed by the President is not in furtherance the vital national security interests of the United States. To date I have heard a great deal from the administration about punishing Bashir al-Assad for violating an “international norm” through the use of chemical weapons, and that this is why we must act against him. Abstract notions about international norms should never displace U.S. sovereignty to act, or refuse to act, for our national security.

Assad’s murderous actions have claimed the lives of more than a hundred thousand of his own people, which is a humanitarian tragedy. But our chief strategic concern should not be international norms; it should be preventing the chemical weapons from falling into the hands of al Qaeda or other terrorists who might use them against us and our allies.

It is now incumbent upon President Obama to make his case and persuade Congress that his plan is necessary, and the best course to preserve our security and protect our liberties. Like the President, I welcome this debate and I agree this is an issue of the highest seriousness that transcends partisan politics.

Unfortunately, all of the concerns that have been repeatedly raised about this bill remain: it repeats the mistakes of the 1986 immigration bill; it grants amnesty first; it won’t secure the border; and it doesn’t fix our broken legal immigration system.

This bill doesn’t solve the problem because the process it went through was fatally flawed– it was written behind closed doors with special interests; in the Judiciary Committee, the Gang of 8 and Democrats blocked all substantive amendments because of a previously cooked deal; and on the Senate floor, the majority blocked any attempts to fix the bill.

Further, in conjunction with Obamacare, the Gang of 8 bill creates a tax enalty on employers – effectively, up to $5,000 – for hiring U.S. citizens or legal immigrants. But that penalty does not apply to those with RPI status, giving a powerful incentive for job creators to hire illegal immigrants instead of U.S. citizens or legal immigrants. That is indefensible. I filed an amendment to fix this defect, but was blocked by Senate Democrats from receiving a vote on that solution.

Sadly, this bill won’t fix the problem with our immigration system and will only encourage more illegal immigration and human suffering.

I strongly support commonsense immigration reform that secures the border before legalization, fixes our legal immigration system, and upholds the rule of law. This bill isn’t it.

From the east side of the Brandenburg Gate, President Obama gave an extraordinary speech today sketching out his plans for a new global order in which traditional national security interests will be replaced by a collective approach to everything from global warming to nuclear weapon capability.

The irony, of course, is that President Obama was free to stand on the formerly-Soviet side of the Brandenburg Gate and opine about global peace with justice because of the strength of the very nuclear arsenal he now proposes to dismantle. While the President claimed today that at the end of the Cold War, “Openness won. Tolerance won. And freedom won here in Berlin,” the reality is that the United States of America won. The Berlin wall did not come down simply because the German people dreamed of freedom. The Berlin came wall down because an American President distilled his policy towards the Soviet Union into a simple formula: “We win, they lose.”

If history be our guide, although the notion of “peace with justice” that the President mentioned ten times in his speech may sound appealing, we will be far better served by President Reagan’s policy of “peace through strength,” which cannot be achieved by appeasement or yet another round of nuclear cuts by the Obama administration.

I'd like to wish all the fathers out there a wonderful Father’s Day. Take your kids to the park, hug them tightly, tell them you love them, and thank God for them and for His many blessings on your family. There’s no more important job than being a father, and a strong, loving Dad gives every child the foundation he or she needs to brave this world. 

My own Dad has been my hero my entire life. He is a man of faith and deep integrity, a man who loves liberty with all his heart. His truly American story of fleeing oppression in Cuba with nothing more than $100 to his name and finding success through hard work and perserverence has inspired me my entire life. Today, my Dad is a pastor, and through his life I have seen every day his love and faith in Jesus. Each Dad should endeavor to reflect our heavenly Father’s love for us, and my Dad has done that throughout my life.

Five years ago, I became a Dad myself, and I learned firsthand just how strong a father’s love could be. There is nothing I would not do for my two daughters. I continue to fight each and every day to preserve this Shining City on a Hill for them–-working to ensure that my girls inherit the same blessed land of liberty and opportunity that each of us has been so priviliged to enjoy–is what keeps me going. For the first time in American history, our children are facing growing up in a country that may well be worse off than it was for the previous generation. This is completely and utterly unacceptable; we cannot selfishly spend away the futures of our children. And I know millions of mothers and fathers across the State share that very same commitment, to turn our country around.

Agriculture forms the backbone of the Texas economy and is an integral part of our proud heritage, as it is for the rest of the nation. Unfortunately, the current farm bill gives far less attention to the needs of farmers than it does to politicians and special interests. For an issue as critical to our nation's safety and American livelihoods as ensuring a reliable food supply, I am disappointed that Washington's cynical politics have again trumped any real reform.

Any meaningful support for farmers in this trillion dollar bill is unnecessarily held hostage to the unchecked growth of food stamp entitlements and numerous other programs unrelated to farming. This farm bill costs 60 percent more than the 2008 bill. Nearly 80 percent of it is comprised of food stamps. It fails to provide a true safety net for difficult years, fails to fully target assistance to those most in need, and fails to prioritize farm aid over duplicative programs, subsidizing unrelated programs from green energy to housing.

We should address the true needs of American farmers, but the bill considered by the Senate does much more harm than good. I hope our House colleagues will include needed reforms that the Senate omitted in its flawed consideration of this important issue.

Today’s unfortunate U.S. Supreme Court ruling in Maryland v. King, by a vote of 5-4, expands government power, invades our liberty, and undermines our constitutional rights. The Court held that the police can forcibly take DNA samples from people who have been arrested—but have not been tried or convicted—of a serious offense. So now the government can capture, without a search warrant, the most personal information about an individual, and use it to search vast databases for unrelated offenses.

All 50 States already collect DNA from convicted felons. So this intrusion of liberty will matter only for those not convicted: the innocent and wrongly accused or those for whom there is insufficient evidence to convict.
There is far too much power in the federal government.

We should always be mindful of the need for government to have the tools necessary to keep Americans safe in a dangerous world, where there are enemies plotting to attack us. We have seen the face of that enemy time and again, most recently in the terrorist attacks at Fort Hood, Benghazi and Boston to name a few.

But on one hand the Obama Administration says this enemy is in retreat, yet on the other, they are implementing what appears to be an unprecedented and intrusive surveillance system on private American citizens in the name of guarding against that enemy. Just today, the president encouraged us to trust him on this – to trust that there are safeguards to ensure our privacy is protected, trust that there is a system of checks and balances to prevent an abuse of power. But in light of this Administration's track record, how can they expect to be trusted?

We have discovered over the past few months an ongoing pattern of wanton disregard not only for Americans' privacy, but for the truth – DOJ's refusal to be forthcoming about drone policy, IRS's targeting groups for their political beliefs and then misleading the American people about it, DOJ's targeting of journalists for doing their jobs, and now what seems an unprecedented intrusion into Americans' personal phone records and potentially into their broader online activities.

Americans trusted President Obama when he came to office promising the most transparent administration in history. But that trust has been broken and the only way to earn it back is to tell the truth. That's what Americans deserve. I will be working with my colleagues in the Senate who share my concerns to ensure that we have all the facts about these surveillance programs, and that our government is appropriately balancing concerns of national security with Americans' personal liberties.

Joint statement with John Cornyn on today's Water Resource and Development Act (WRDA) vote:

Texas has taken significant steps to ensure a robust water infrastructure in the years to come as our state remains one of the fastest growing in the nation. The WRDA legislation that passed through the Senate today contains numerous meritorious projects we support, including those of national scope and that are important to Texas. However, this bill fails to fix an incredibly ineffective system.

For instance, the bill neglects to reduce a substantial backlog of projects, to the detriment of projects with national implications, such as the Sabine-Neches Waterway that has taken 14 years to get approval just to begin construction. Additionally, it expands the Army Corps of Engineers' responsibilities without providing adequate measures for state participation, and eliminates measures designed to ensure projects stay on budget.

Our hope is that we can work with our House colleagues to fix the problems in this bill and ensure an effective and accountable system for water supply and navigation needs in Texas.

Great op-ed in the Wall Street Journal today that highlights a major problem with the Internet sales tax. How is the law supposed to make the marketplace more fair when it subjects online retailers to standards above and beyond those of brick-and-mortar stores?
 
"Proponents of the bill, which they call the Marketplace Fairness Act, say they're just leveling the playing field between bricks-and-mortar stores and online stores. It's true that many online stores benefit from not charging sales tax, but they also don't use the services of states where they have little or no presence. Online stores would have to do something physical stores have never done for most sales: assess taxes based on where their customer lives. Physical stores apply their own local tax to most purchases."
Thanks to the FreedomWorks grassroots activists for all your hard work fighting for liberty!

Today, it was an honor to attend the dedication of the George W. Bush Presidential Library and Museum, as well as a memorial ceremony remembering those lost in the tragic explosion in West, Texas.

Unfortunately, the Senate Majority Leader scheduled the vote on the Internet sales tax bill while I was in Texas. Had I been present for the vote, I would have emphatically voted ‘no.’

Restoring economic growth should be every elected official's top priority. Our economy is stagnant--it's grown just 0.8% a year for the last four years--and small businesses are gasping for breath.

At a time when so many people are hurting, this bill would impose billions of dollars of new taxes on small businesses across America. That makes no sense.

The Internet has been a haven for entrepreneurial growth. We should protect and cherish the freedom of the Internet, and Congress should not pass a massive new Internet sales tax.

The Democratic leadership should not be doing the bidding of major corporate lobbyists, at the expense of mom-and-pop retailers across America. Forcing small Internet retailers to comply with the taxing authority of over 9600 jurisdictions nationwide would kill jobs and stifle economic growth. There's no reason for the Senate to pass this flawed bill--skipping the committee process and rushing the bill forward to stifle debate.

It was an honor to attend the opening of President Bush’s library today and pay tribute to our former president’s legacy. President Bush is a man of character and profound decency. And his resilience and strength of character, especially in the challenging days after 9/11, helped bring America together and get our nation back on its feet.

Today was a bipartisan celebration of that character, that resiliency, that legacy. I was proud to serve on his presidential campaign--where I met my wife and the mother of our children--and I'm proud that Dallas and SMU will be the home of this incredible testament to George W. Bush's leadership.

Why did the Senate vote on a gun bill no one had even read? Joint statement with United States Senator Mike Lee and Senator Rand Paul:

This morning the Senate will vote on the motion to proceed to the firearms bill (S.649). It is expected that the Toomey-Manchin provision announced yesterday will replace the current language regarding background checks. Yet, as of this morning, not a single senator has been provided the legislative language of this provision. Because the background-check measure is the centerpiece of this legislation it is critical that we know what is in the bill before we vote on it. The American people expect more and deserve better.

Today the world mourns the loss of an extraordinary leader, the great Margaret Thatcher.

Utterly fearless, she never would go wobbly. Rejecting the failures of socialism, she won the argument for liberty, and her name is synonymous with the policies that restored peace, prosperity, growth, and stability at a time when it seemed like the United Kingdom had none.

It was truly a Providential blessing that she served alongside President Ronald Reagan and Pope John Paul II -- together the three of them stood unshakable, defended humanity, and won the Cold War without firing a shot. Her magnificent intellect and unwavering work ethic helped her ascend to become Britain's first and only female prime minister; it wasn't a matter of breaking through the glass ceiling, but simply refusing to acknowledge its existence.

Lady Thatcher was one of kind, and the world will forever be in her debt. Long live the memory of our dearly departed Iron Lady.

The Constitution assigns Congress the power of the purse and the responsibility to appropriate federal funds. Congress should take up that obligation, pass a budget, and finally get serious about reducing federal spending. Today, forty-six cents of every dollar the federal government spends is borrowed. Our national debt exceeds the size of our entire economy, threatening future generations. And, in the face of these grave economic challenges, Washington, DC, is agonizing over a 2.4 percent cut.

We need to cut a lot more than 2.4 percent. We should adjust the sequester so that it does not disproportionately target vital defense spending. Instead, Congress and the President should work together to eliminate government waste, and no government agency should be exempt from scrutiny where savings can be achieved. In fact, in a report issued just today Citizens Against Government Waste offers many promising suggestions, outlining $1.8 trillion in specific savings over five years.

The Obama Administration has the ability to implement the sequester so as to avoid damaging national security and compromising the best interests of Americans. The only reason it might do otherwise would be to score partisan political points.

Chuck Hagel will be confirmed because Senate Democrats stood united behind President Obama's nomination of the most controversial Secretary of Defense in modern times. No one has ever been confirmed to the position with more than 11 "no" votes, until today when a record number of senators voted against his nomination. 

A great many of us have been concerned about Hagel's longstanding record of antagonism towards Israel and unwillingness to stand vigorously against Iran's acquiring nuclear weapons. I hope those concerns are proven wrong. 

I fervently hope that this confirmation does not embolden Iran to accelerate their nuclear weapons development; I fervently hope that this confirmation does not undermine our vital alliance with Israel. 

Chuck Hagel can prove his critics wrong by standing by his confirmation commitments. He has an enormous task ahead of him, and running the Defense Department will require principled leadership on the world’s stage. I wish Secretary Hagel success in his new role and am committed to working with him to keep America safe and strong.

Today the Senate rightly voted to continue debate on Sen. Chuck Hagel's nomination. There is no reason to rush his nomination to a vote until he has adequately responded to multiple requests from members of the Armed Services Committee for additional information.

Twenty-five senators have asked Senator Hagel to disclose the personal compensation that he has received the past five years, and twice he has flat-out refused regarding what he was paid in 2008, 2009, and 2010. This is within his direct control, and his refusal to comply with this reasonable request is troubling. Both Henry Kissinger and Hillary Clinton were asked similar questions, and given the vital importance of the Secretary of Defense to our national security, Sen. Hagel should not be held to a lesser standard.

Once Senator Hagel responds to these reasonable requests to disclose whether and to what extent he has any foreign financial conflicts of interest, I am confident that a bipartisan majority of the Senate will move forward to the timely consideration of the merits of his nomination.

Every parent was understandably horrified by the senseless murder of 20 children and 6 adults at an elementary school in Newtown, CT. Our hearts weep for the families, and we are appropriately engaged in a national discussion about the problems of mental illness and the approaches that state and local governments can take to prevent future tragedies.

Sadly, but predictably, it took just minutes for liberals to begin exploiting this horror to push their own gun-control schemes. One media pundit after another blathered on about their deep desire to strip away our Second Amendment rights — despite the fact that no gun-control laws could possibly have prevented this madman from stealing guns from a law-abiding citizen and murdering these children.

President Obama leapt on the bandwagon, renewing his call to come after our guns. And Senator Feinstein reintroduced an even more aggressive “assault weapons ban” that would, among other things, create a national firearms registry — a government list of those Americans who choose to exercise our constitutional rights.

This is wrong, and I will fight to stop it. It contravenes the Bill of Rights, and it is foolhardy policy — consistently, those jurisdictions that enact the most restrictive firearms policies have the highest crime and murder rates, and those jurisdictions that protect our right to keep and bear arms have the lowest.

Sign this national petition if you believe we must protect our Second Amendment rights. Stand together to make clear that politicians shouldn’t use horrible tragedies as an excuse to trample on our constitutional right to keep and bear arms.

RIP Judge Robert Bork, a pioneer who helped lead a transformation of American law. Judge Bork's brilliant and fearless scholarship ushered in a renewed focus on the original understanding of the Constitution, a reorientation of antitrust law away from business regulation and towards competition, and a retreat from the liberal judicial activism of the 60s and 70s. He will be missed.

Great news for U.S. sovereignty: Today, the Senate narrowly rejected the U.N. Disabilities Treaty, which would have done very little to benefit those with disabilities but would have subjected the United States to an overseas, unaccountable "board of experts" at the United Nations. 

Although it’s encouraging that the treaty was rejected, the fact that it was so close—61 Senators voted to ratify the treaty—demonstrates the need for all of us to remain vigilant defending U.S. sovereignty. This fight will keep coming, and only accelerate in the next four years.

Yesterday, members of our armed services in Chattanooga, Tennessee, went to work in the service of our nation. Some went to a recruiting center to assist the young people who, like so many before them, would walk through the door on any given Thursday morning and volunteer to defend the United States of America. Four brave Marines went to a Naval Reserve Center to perform their duties to the Tennessee National Guard.

But one of the young people who visited two of those facilities was not like the others. He was there not to volunteer to serve America, but to attack America. Mohammod Youssuf Abdulazeez was there to carry out jihad, an act of radical Islamic terrorism. An act of war, in which those four brave Marines lost their lives, while at least two others were wounded.

In the wake of this vicious attack on our nation we need to rid ourselves of two dangerous delusions, first and foremost that a "lone gunman"–as President Obama described the shooter–is somehow isolated from the larger threat of radical Islamic terrorism. In the modern world, no one acts in isolation. Through social media ISIS, al Qaida and other groups are infiltrating our nation with impunity while our government will not even admit that radical Islamic terrorism is a problem.

The second delusion is that this attack is somehow isolated from previous episodes, notably those in Little Rock, Arkansas and Fort Hood, Texas, in 2009—both of which were attacks on American military facilities. The Obama administration was woefully reluctant to call either an act of radical Islamic terrorism, instead suggesting "workplace violence" as a justification for the killings. Finally, after years of effort, the victims of Fort Hood were properly recognized as victims of attacks by foreign terrorists when they received Purple Hearts on April 15, 2015. Likewise, the victim of the Little Rock attack received a Purple Heart on July 1, 2015.

We cannot afford wait six years to recognize what happened yesterday in Chattanooga for what it was. We need to see with clarity right now what has happened. We can immediately hold hearings in the Senate Armed Services Committee on the need for our enlisted men and women to have the right to be armed in military facilities. Congress can pass the Expatriate Terrorist Act that would allow our government to stop Americans who travel overseas to train with terrorist groups from coming back to attack us at home. We can thoroughly overhaul our broken immigration system that is allowing this type of individual to gain citizenship. And we can accept the reality that while we might wish it otherwise, the forces of radical Islam are at war with us.

The Texas & Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association knows firsthand that we have got to stop the Obama Administration's abusive enforcement of environmental laws. 

LIKE if you agree!

A trifecta: liberal stupidity, anti-gun bias, and abusive enforcement of environmental laws. Three specias--the scimitar-horned oryx, the addax, and the dama gazelle--were nearly extinct, until Texas ranchers began raising them. Their view: "We love the animals so much, we would rather all three species go extinct than have a single hunter fire a shot." Nuts.

This week, we give thanks to God for the many blessings that have made America such an extraordinary nation. Our founders knew that trusting our liberty to men–who are not angels–would never be enough to secure our freedom. Instead, they made this a nation of laws, crafted a Constitution to “bind the mischief of government,” and invoked the favor of Providence to watch over America.

Without God’s blessings, our freedoms could never endure, despite the best efforts of men and women. With God’s favor, our Nation will overcome and prosper, even in hours that seem the darkest.

This Thanksgiving, Heidi and I wish you and your family the very best, and may God continue to bless the United States of America.

Ronald Reagan, Margaret Thatcher, and Pope John Paul II exemplified the courage to speak the truth and stand up in the face of oppression. It was a wonderful testament to liberty, and we owe it to our children and grandchildren to continue the fight to preserve freedom in America and across the globe.

We’ve just announced that we’re providing more teacher aide support for 1250 kids who have additional learning needs.
Great to open new buildings at Samuel Marsden Collegiate School this morning.
I'll be on Newstalk ZB on the Tim Fookes Morning Show from 10am. Looking forward to taking your calls.
Finance Minister Bill English offers a sneak peek of Budget 2016.
I’ve just joined LinkedIn. Click the below to head on over, follow my profile, and stay up to date as I share my thoughts on some of the big issues facing New Zealand and the Asia Pacific region.
Earlier this week I outlined why TPP is our most significant free trade deal to date.
Great to speak to the New Zealand National Party's Northern Convention this afternoon about how well the country is doing.
Happy Mother's Day to all the mums out there. I hope you're getting breakfast in bed or something nice coming your way.
Good luck to the New Zealand Kiwis for their test against the Kangaroos tonight!
Visited the impressive setup at Indevin where they provide world-class facilities for Marlborough's local wine makers.
Great to bump into this bunch from GirlGuiding New Zealand today and to see them having such a good time at their national forum.
Spoke and met with senior students from both Marlborough Girls’ and Boys’ Colleges.
We've announced the Electric Vehicle Programme, an ambitious plan that will make electric vehicles more accessible to New Zealanders. #EVFutureNZ
We're committed to strengthening New Zealand's cyber security capability.
Great to meet Kiwi rally driver and WRC Rally Argentina winner Hayden Paddon.

A privilege to join Hekia Parata and celebrate our best students at the NZQA Top Scholar Awards, including Rutherford College student Oxana Repina who received the Prime Minister’s Award for Academic Excellence.
I'll be doing a Facebook live chat tomorrow with Stuff.co.nz from 7.45am. Looking forward to answering a few of your questions.
I'll be answering your questions in a Stuff.co.nz Facebook live chat in just a few minutes time.
TPP will open up access to 800 million people around the world.
Fortress New Zealand simply doesn’t work.
Met with Indian President Pranab Mukharjee today, the first time an Indian Head of State has visited New Zealand
Spent the day meeting with community leaders and locals in Otorohanga and Te Kuiti.
Dropped into the Motueka Family Service Centre with local MP Maureen Pugh MP to hear about the great work they’re doing helping families.
NZ now has a fantastic white water park for families to enjoy and athletes to train at. It's another world class facility for Auckland.
The government will invest $9.4m in new buildings at Auckland's Riverhead School. We're proud to be investing in more schools and classrooms to support our young people.
Lest we forget.
Supporting NZ’s film industry at the launch of the NZ Film Festival in Shanghai.
Wishing Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II a very happy 90th birthday.
More great news for our tourism sector with this deal set to inject $50m into our economy.
Enjoyed a Mojo coffee in Xi’an. Great to see another Kiwi company establishing itself in the Chinese market.
Met with Chinese President Xi Jinping last night to discuss upgrading our free trade agreement, our term on the UN Security Council, and Helen Clark's Secretary-General bid.
Received a warm welcome from Premier Li Keqiang in Beijing’s Great Hall of the People
Pleased to meet one of China’s most influential and successful business leaders - Jack Ma, founder and Executive Chairman of Alibaba.
Today I'm heading off on an important trip to China to build on our growing relationship with our largest export partner.

Had a busy schedule in Christchurch yesterday, including popping in to visit the team at Antarctica New Zealand, meeting with the Community Forum, opening the new BNZ Centre that will be home to Government employees in the CBD, and checking out the refurbished Sudima Hotel at Christchurch Airport.
Great to see NZ voted the best country to visit for the fourth year in a row in The Telegraph's awards.
Today I announced tax changes that will save businesses $180 million over four years.
Made sure I got my flu jab this afternoon, joining more than one million New Zealanders who will be immunised against influenza this year.
I’ve just announced tax changes to help small businesses focus on creating jobs and grow the economy.
Some great questions from students at Rosehill College in Papakura today with local MP Judith Collins. Encouraging to see young people thinking about the future of NZ.

With the completion of Hamilton’s Ultra-Fast Broadband build there are now 875,000 customers around New Zealand who can connect to faster internet speeds. With the national rollout 60 per cent complete, we’re helping Kiwis, schools, hospitals and businesses overcome the tyranny of distance and better connect with the world.

Opened the new Gallagher Agribusiness Centre of Excellence at St Paul’s Collegiate School in Hamilton, an initiative designed to help meet the growing need for qualified graduates to sustain the future of our primary industries.
The New Zealand Government is pleased to nominate Helen Clark for the position of the United Nations Secretary-General.
Catching up with the Republic of Korea's President Park and Japan's PM Abe at the Nuclear Security Summit in Washington.

Discussed the TPP, NZ's first free trade agreement with the US, and other economic issues with Jeff Zients - US director of the National Economic Council and assistant to President Obama for economic policy.
Caught up with Netherlands PM Mark Rutte at the Nuclear Security summit in Washington.
On a scoping mission to see if Moonbeam would like the First Dog.
I've just arrived in Washington where I'll spend the next two days meeting with trade and economic leaders before attending the Nuclear Security Summit.
Happy Easter!
Arrived in Paris overnight ahead of the #COP21 climate change meeting.
Toured ASB Theatre in Blenheim with Stuart Smith MP. We’ve just announced $1 million to help with the theatre’s development.
Stuart Smith MP and I joined the Marlborough Cancer Society for an early celebration of Mother’s Day with a morning tea.
We've just announced $124 million in additional funding for Pharmac over the next four years. This means Pharmac can fund more drugs, including new specialist cancer drugs.
This Government knows we can compete and we will succeed.
Met with French Prime Minister Manuel Valls this morning where we discussed trade, our mutual interest in the Pacific, and the international response to terrorism.
Great to speak to New Zealand National Party members at our Central North Island regional conference in Hamilton today.
Caught up with the hard working team at New Zealand Hops who are busy packaging up this year’s harvest.
Getting a few gardening tips, and a tasty snack, from the talented team at Waimea Nurseries.
It's just 100 days until the Rio Olympics and as our athletes are going through their final preparations, we're ready to cheer them on to success.
Spoke with young New Zealanders in Mt Roskill tonight. I told them to have faith in NZ and to work hard to make it better.
Pleasure to speak with members of the West Auckland Business Club today, including about the opportunities opening up for them in Asia.
Today we remember those who fought for the values that underpin our country.
I joined thousands of other Kiwis this morning in remembering those who have served our country.
Last week I was fortunate to be able to spend the day in Invercargill and Stewart Island, an incredible part of the country.
Walked along the old city wall in China's cultural capital of Xi'an.
At Xi’an’s Terracotta Warriors museum – a truly impressive sight.
Visited Xi’an’s International Trade and Logistics Park, China’s first inland port and an important transport hub.
Congratulations to Dan Carter and the All Blacks on their wins at the Laureus Sports Awards.
Helped the Wellington Phoenix FC celebrate the renewal of their sponsorship with Huawei.

I was pleased to be in Beijing this morning to witness the signing of a significant agreement between NZ company NHNZ and China Central TV (CCTV). The companies will work together to co-produce a number of TV shows for the Chinese market in a deal worth millions of dollars. New Zealand is the only country with both film and TV co-production agreements with China, and it’s great to see a Kiwi company making the most of the agreement.
Arrived in Beijing last night on my sixth official visit to China.
Had a fantastic time on Friday with local MP Sarah Dowie MP. We started the day in Invercargill before visiting Stewart Island and Ulva Island.
Click below for the highlights from my announcement today that will save small businesses time and money.
Be one of the first to hear my pre-Budget announcement on Wednesday.
Get a sneak peek of my first Budget 2016 announcement that I’ll be making on Wednesday.
Our world-class SAS troops and the NZDF will be incredibly well served by the impressive new Battle Training Facility I opened today.
Privilege to open the new $7m science block at Otahuhu College and to see such a focus among the students on science.
I was joined by local MPs David Bennett MP and Tim Macindoe MP to help the Institute of Directors celebrate 25 years of being in the Waikato.
Addressing the Nuclear Security Summit in Washington - New Zealand takes our responsibility of ensuring nuclear and radioactive materials in our country are safeguarded very seriously.
Tonight I attended the opening of the Nuclear Security Summit. New Zealand is committed to the goal of securing vulnerable nuclear materials worldwide.
I talked with UK Prime Minister David Cameron today about a wide range of issues, including the EU referendum.

On 1 April Kiwi families will be better off with 18 weeks paid parental leave, an increase in the minimum wage to $15.25, $25 more a week and increased work obligations for beneficiaries with children, and around $12.50 more a week through Working for Families.
Spoke to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce about the global economy, trade and the TPP.
Good luck to our Blackcaps and White Ferns for their T20 World Cup semi-finals. Keep doing us proud.
Saddened to hear about the death of Frank Torley, the iconic voice of Country Calendar for nearly 50 years.

New Zealand has voted to retain our current flag and I’m proud that more than 2 million New Zealanders participated in this important discussion and referendum on our national identity. Now a flag has been decided I encourage all New Zealanders to use it, embrace it and, more importantly, be proud of it.

This Easter weekend I hope you have a great break with family and friends, and remember to stay safe on our roads. I'm travelling to Washington DC for the fourth Nuclear Security Summit hosted by President Barack Obama.
This week I popped out to Hutt South with locally based MP Chris Bishop. Managed to even get some sparring lessons at the Naenae Boxing Academy.
Ever wonder what a day in my life looks like when Parliament isn’t sitting? Here’s the highlights from my recent visit through the Otaki electorate.
Met Anjalee and Burma at Auckland Zoo this afternoon.
Visited the innovative team at Rex Bionics who specialise in enhancing the mobility of wheelchair users.
Great to visit Rangitoto College with local MP Murray McCully this morning to meet with student leaders.
Our thoughts are with Belgians in the aftermath of the shocking attacks in Brussels overnight.
The Blackcaps and White Ferns are both two from two at the T20 World Cup in India. There's tough games coming up, but we're all 100 per cent behind you.
Local MP Matt Doocey and I had an interesting tour of Rangiora’s new volunteer fire brigade building today.
Jack have I got the deal for you - two pandas for two kiwi and I will throw in a set of steak knives.
Met with Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif this afternoon - the first visit by an Iranian Foreign Minister to New Zealand in a decade.

I was surprised and honoured last night at a dinner I was hosting for the Rotary Club of Auckland (CBD) as they presented me a Paul Harris Fellowship. Truly humbling given the incredible work Rotarians do in our communities.
Today we introduced legislation to create the Kermadec Ocean Sanctuary, one of the largest ocean sanctuaries in the world.

We’re a Government that’s focused on the issues that matter, whether it’s growing the economy to create jobs and raise wages, through to lifting NCEA achievement rates, we’re focused on the issues that really matter to New Zealanders.
Dropped into Massey University's O Week celebrations this afternoon with local MP Jono Naylor.
Sad to hear of the passing of Martin Crowe today. A true legend of New Zealand sport. Our thoughts are with his family.

Our thoughts are with the people of Fiji following the devastation and loss of life caused by Cyclone Winston. We’re providing practical support on the ground and we’ll continue to assist in any way we can.
Today we announced the minimum wage will be increasing to $15.25 from 1 April 2016, a 3.4% increase.
An honour to visit Sri Lanka's Sri Dalada Maligawa - one of their most sacred temples.
Well done Max, great to see you doing so well!
Spectacular welcome in Colombo this morning ahead of my meeting with President Maithripala Sirisena and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe.

Pleased to arrive in Sri Lanka today. Thank you to Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe who came out at midnight to welcome me at the airport. The country has made huge progress since its civil war and New Zealand is helping with those efforts.
Moving service to remember the 185 people who lost their lives in the 2011 Canterbury earthquake.
Today we reflect on the Christchurch earthquake of 22 February 2011. We remember those who we lost, we reflect on how far we’ve come since, and look forward to what the future for the city holds.
Enjoying the beautiful Sydney harbour with Malcolm Turnbull.
What a way to mark your final game Brendon McCullum, fastest century in test history! What an innings!

Great news today for Kiwis living in Australia with Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announcing a new pathway to citizenship. This is a positive step towards recognising the significant contribution New Zealanders living in Australia make to Australian society and means more Kiwis who have made their lives there will be able to enjoy the same rights and entitlements as other Australians.

Congratulations to all the winners at last night’s Halberg Awards. Great to see so many New Zealanders doing so well on the world stage and being recognised for those efforts.
Just touched down in Sydney ahead of the annual Trans-Tasman Leaders' meeting with Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull.

Excited to turn the first sod on the International Convention Centre in Auckland, a project that will create 1,000 jobs during construction, and another 1,140 once complete, as well as provide New Zealand with a world-class facility which is expected bring an additional $90 million in tourism expenditure annually.
Looking forward to taking your calls on Newstalk ZB's Tim Fookes Morning Show from 10am.
The Margaret Mahy Family Playground in central Christchurch is impressive - it was lovely to see lots of families having fun there today.
Great to visit the Ōtākaro Orchard community garden in central Christchurch this morning with Nicky Wagner
Visited the Southern Field Days at Waimumu this afternoon. Great to catch up with farmers of all ages.
Unveiled Carterton's new Charles Rooking Carter statue which commemorates the town's founder
The students at Masterton’s St Matthew's Collegiate did a great job showing me around their school this morning.
Bumped into Valerie Adams and DJ Forbes while on a tour of AUT's Millennium Institute.
An absolute pleasure this morning to have Steve and Kath from The Breeze Wellington and all the kids up at Premier House for the Great Easter Egg Hunt.
I've just announced the next Governor-General of New Zealand - Dame Patsy Reddy, who will take over from Sir Jerry Mateparae on 14 September.

Dame Patsy Reddy is thoughtful, articulate and has a brilliant legal mind. I am sure New Zealanders will be proud to have her as our next Governor-General.
https://www.national.org.nz/news/news/media-releases/detail/2016/03/21/PM-welcomes-Dame-Patsy-Reddy-as-the-next-Governor-General
Amazing atmosphere at Polyfest in Auckland this afternoon. Make sure you head along this weekend.

Opened Enterprise North Canterbury's new business hub in Kaiapoi today which will help promote economic growth in the region. It was a pleasure to meet Corbin Tait who showed me his latest school project.
Checking out progress on the Western Belfast Bypass, which will provide better and safer links throughout greater Christchurch when complete.
Our tourism industry is growing strongly, creating new jobs and opportunities for Kiwis and showcasing our country to the world.
We're delivering better public services for Kiwi families.

Simon Bridges MP and I were joined by local MPs David Bennett MP and Lindsay Tisch MP to get work underway on the Hamilton section of the Waikato Expressway, the largest roading project in the region’s history.
A privilege to open Te Mahi Hou at Marsden Point Refinery, a $365m project that employed 650 contractors over three years.
Great to get the Hundertwasser Art Centre underway in Whangarei with local MP Shane Reti. Once finished it'll be a truly iconic building.
My thoughts are with the officers injured in Kawerau today and with their families and colleagues.

Today is International Children’s Day. As a Government we take our responsibility seriously to try and provide for every child, regardless of their background, so they can have the best possible start in life.
Stopped in to see the staff working on the City Rail Link, a project that will double capacity on Auckland's rail network and reduce travel time for commuters.
Rousing welcome at Palmerston North Girls' High School for local MP Jono Naylor and me this afternoon.
A quick wrap up of my trip to Sri Lanka last week.
Chaired a meeting of the International Democrat Union in Colombo today.
More great news for our growing tourism industry.

Today I met with Sri Lankan President Maithripala Sirisena and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe to discuss business opportunities between New Zealand and Sri Lanka and launched two dairy development projects aimed at helping local farmers.

On 22 February 2011 the Christchurch earthquake claimed the lives of 185 people. Today I joined the people of Christchurch to pause and remember those lives lost, to look back at how far the city’s rebuild has come from that day, and to also look ahead with excitement to the future and all the possibilities it holds for them. 

I’d personally like to thank the people of Christchurch who are optimistic about the future of their city. We know there’s still more to do to help Christchurch achieve its goal of becoming New Zealand’s most liveable city, and I remain committed to helping you achieve that goal.
Fabulous evening for a ferry ride in Sydney with Malcolm Turnbull and Lucy Turnbull.
Received a warm welcome from NSW Premier Mike Baird and his Cabinet today.

Today Malcolm Turnbull and I are meeting to discuss a wide range of issues spanning from opportunities for further trans-Tasman collaboration on trade, regional and security issues, through to continuing to discuss the situation of New Zealanders living in Australia, and the ongoing management of deportations from Australia.
Here are more great reasons why we should change our flag.
An absolute privilege last night to present Richie McCaw with his New Zealander of the Year award. Congratulations!
Budget 2016 will set out the next steps in the Government’s programme to provide more opportunities for Kiwis as well as support more jobs and higher incomes.
The LGBTI community is one of the most vibrant and welcoming - it was great to catch up with many of its members and other Aucklanders at the Big Gay Out today.
Thinking of the people of Christchurch. The earthquake this afternoon would have been unsettling but pleased to hear there's been no reports of injuries or any major damage.
I agree with you Bill. Stick to trimming budgets, not shearing sheep.
Congratulations to all those involved in the tourism sector for their hard work.
An honour to present the cap for Brendon McCullum's 100th test. A truly great cricketer and New Zealander. Best of luck to Brendon and the team tomorrow.
Attended a very colourful Chinese New Year celebration at Parliament tonight to welcome the Year of the Monkey.
Gong Xi Fa Cai! Happy Chinese New Year! Wishing you luck and prosperity in the Year of the Monkey.
Later this week I’m heading south to the Southern Field Days - Waimumu near Gore, which will be a good chance to chat to farmers and those in the rural sector
Today I gave my first speech in Parliament for 2016. I talked about the current state of the economy, free trade and our priorities for the year.

It was a pleasure to present Tim Groser with a silver tray to mark his time as an MP and Minister at the first National Caucus meeting for 2016. We wish him all the best for his new role as New Zealand’s Ambassador to the United States.
Great to spend Waitangi Day at the NRL Auckland Nines where the atmosphere was fantastic.
Later today the Trans-Pacific Partnership will be signed in Auckland. This agreement is overwhelmingly positive for New Zealand – it will support more trade and investment, jobs and higher incomes.

Thursday 7 February was a significant day for New Zealand with the signing of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) in Auckland. Watch below where I dispel the misinformation that’s been circulated about the TPP, and explain why it is such a good deal for New Zealanders.
The 2016 Chappell-Hadlee ODI series kicks off between the Black Caps and the Aussies today in Auckland and like all Kiwis I’ll be cheering them on to victory! Good luck to Brendon and the boys.
Bronagh and I were on the BBQ tonight as we welcomed the start of the Parliamentary year with the National Caucus at Premier House
An absolute pleasure to meet the lovely Jessie Robb who turns 90 today and was celebrating with her family. Happy Birthday Jessie!
I’ve just announced several key infrastructure projects, including bringing Auckland’s City Rail Link forward by two years.
Nathan Guy and I popped along to the Karaka Yearling Sales today, an event that attracts buyers from around the world.
Sign up on the link below to be one of the first to hear the announcements from my first major speech of the year next week.
The second royal visit of 2015 saw Their Royal Highnesses The Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwell touring the country.
Our careful economic management saw New Zealand become one of the first OECD countries to get back in the black after the Global Financial Crisis.
The announcement of a deal on TPP opens the door for our businesses to export even more to some of the world’s largest economies.
At twice the size of New Zealand, the announcement of the Kermadec Ocean Sanctuary was a big win for marine conservation.
It’s exciting that our tourist numbers are booming as the rest of the world catches on to our little slice of paradise.
In the 2014 election we promised to double the support for first home buyers, and our new HomeStart package has already doubled the rate of Kiwis receiving help to get into their first home.
It was great to once again visit Fieldays where the very best of our primary industries are on show.
In #Budget2015 we became the first government in 43 years to raise benefits outside of inflation adjustments, as part of a wider package to support children living in hardship.
Always great to bring a smile to deserving young Kiwis like at Easter when I helped host the Premier House Easter Egg Hunt.
While we didn’t get the result we wanted in the final, the BLACKCAPS still made us incredibly proud in the ICC Cricket World Cup, including a thrilling win over Australia at Eden Park.
I started 2015 by attending the World Economic Forum at Davos in Switzerland.
We’re using assets seized from criminals to support valuable anti-drug initiatives.
Officially welcomed Judith Collins back into Cabinet today.
Great to visit parishioners at the Free Church of Tonga in Mangere this morning.
Opened Canterbury Rugby Football Union’s new training facilities at Rugby Park.
As 2015 draws to a close, I thought I'd share some of my personal highlights from what's been a busy year for the National-led Government.
New Zealand is taking the lead in urging Japan not to resume whaling.
A big thank you to Charlotte Barclay who invited me to speak at the Year 6 graduation at Victoria Avenue School last night.
Bronagh and I visited the incredible street art at the East Side Gallery memorial of the Berlin Wall.

I’ve presented United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change Executive Secretary Christiana Figueres a message from close to 40 nations calling for the removal of fossil fuel subsidies. #COP21
I’ve announced we’ll make an additional contribution to help research to reduce global agricultural emissions. #COP21
Overnight Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and I paid our respects to the victims of the recent terrorist attacks in France.
Bronagh and I laid a wreath at the Pieta Military Cemetery in Valletta, Malta, which includes the graves of more than 60 men from the New Zealand Expeditionary Force in World War One.
Met with new Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at CHOGM today.
Next steps in mixed ownership programme  - Hon Bill English
Impressive effort by the Warriors for making the finals. Congratulations to the Kiwi Ferns on their outstanding NRL Auckland Nines series win. Job well done.
Caught up with league legend Mal Meninga, and also congratulated Joseph Parker on his rise to #1 top contender with the WBO while at the NRL Auckland Nines.
As Prime Minister, I work every day to lead a more open and confident country that backs itself on the world stage. The Trans-Pacific Partnership is an important part of that.
I’m taking part in a live chat at Stuff.co.nz now to answer questions on the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
Great to be in Auckland today for the signing of the Trans-Pacific Partnership with New Zealand Trade Minister Todd McClay and Ministers representing the other 11 Trans-Pacific Partnership countries.
Good news today for Kiwi families. Our focus on the economy is leading to more jobs, higher wages and lower unemployment.
Delighted to hear Christchurch’s amazing new Margaret Mahy Family Playground has been a hit with families, with more than 100,000 people visiting it in the first six weeks.
My new website is now live. Head on over and take a look, and don't forget to sign up to my email newsletter while you're there.

Great weekend of sporting results for New Zealand. Congratulations to the NZ7s team and the Black Caps, as well as Molly & Alex Sailing for winning gold at the Sailing World Cup in Miami and Jossi Wells as the first Kiwi to win gold at the Winter X Games.
For all those students returning or starting school this week, have a great year and make the most of the opportunities ahead of you.

For New Zealand to succeed, Auckland must succeed.
https://www.national.org.nz/news/features/auckland
Today I gave my first major speech of the year. Watch below to hear the important announcements from it.
A sneak peek of what’s in my first speech for 2016 tomorrow.
Catching up on some Cabinet papers ahead of the first Cabinet meeting of 2016.
Was good to be back at Ratana today where I talked about the TPP and education.
Great to meet NZ’s future leaders at the PM’s Youth Programme Dinner, and hip hop star Parris Goebel.
Enjoyed meeting with German Chancellor Angela Merkel in Berlin last year, a world leader who I truly admire.
Always great to catch up with President Barack Obama.
Probably one of the biggest highlights of 2015 for the entire country has to be the All Blacks winning back-to-back Rugby World Cups.
I was honoured to be able to visit our soldiers at Camp Taji in Iraq last year, where working hard to equip the Iraqi Army with the skills needed to fight ISIL.
It was an honour to have the opportunity to speak at the United Nations in New York last year.
No pressure, but Paul Henry put me on the spot to name 9 national currencies in 10 seconds to win a prize for Ronald McDonald House.
From 1 July 2015 our package of free GP visits and prescriptions for children under 13 came into effect, a big help for Kiwi families.
We announced the largest ever investment in urban cycleways in New Zealand’s history, and some of the projects are already well underway.
Happy New Year!
In the first of two royal visits, Prince Harry toured the country, starting in Wellington.
It was hugely moving to be able to attend the commemorations at Gallipoli marking 100 years since ANZAC forces landed there.
Merry Christmas New Zealand.
For me, Christmas is all about family and friends, and maybe eating a little too much! Have a very merry Christmas, a happy New Year, and a safe and relaxing holiday season.
I was saddened to hear the passing of Jon Gadsby. A character who will be remembered for his sense of humour, and his work with David McPhail.
Nathan Guy and I dropped into the race meeting at Ellerslie, even had a cheeky punt too.
David Carter and I got a few pointers on flying at Christchurch Helicopters.
Popped into visit the team at Airways at Christchurch International Airport along with Speaker David Carter and Richie McCaw.
Had a great time at the Special Children's Christmas Party in Auckland this afternoon, including the important task of helping Jack pick his present.
Louise Upston MP and I got a sneak preview of the upcoming Track Cycling World Cup at the Avantidrome in Cambridge.
Great to meet with German Chancellor Angela Merkel in Berlin and continue to build on the close friendship between our countries.

Pleased to announce in Berlin that the joint venture between The University of Auckland’s Bioengineering Institute and Germany’s Fraunhofer IPA will receive additional funding to help their work in developing bionic joints.
Had productive meetings at #COP21 with Irish Taoiseach Enda Kenny, Peruvian President Ollanta Humala, and Dutch Minister-president Mark Rutte.

NZ supports a new initiative announced by the Queen to protect rainforest and native forest throughout the Commonwealth. 
https://www.national.org.nz/news/news/media-releases/detail/2015/11/27/pm-welcomes-queen-s-commonwealth-canopy-initiative
Our $435m HomeStart scheme is on track to help 90,000 Kiwis into their first homes over the next five years.
Today we celebrated 40 years of diplomatic relations with ASEAN. We will now work more closely with the region including increasing our investment there.
NZ is supporting the Philippine Red Cross to improve their ability to respond to disasters. Today I opened a warehouse for supplies which we helped build.
Great to catch up with President Barack Obama and other leaders today at the TPP Leaders' meeting to mark the successful TPP negotiations.
Pleasure to meet Chinese President Xi and Malaysian PM Najib today - we gave PM Najib a book of news reports from his father's visit to NZ in 1967.
Deeply saddened to hear of Jonah Lomu’s unexpected passing this morning. The thoughts of the entire country are with his family.
Yesterday I met with leaders of Viet Nam's Parliament and Communist Party who are enthusiastic about working more closely with New Zealand.
Steven Joyce and I got to try our hand at air traffic control with some of Viet Nam’s New Zealand trained staff.
Robbed in a cook-off against Steven Joyce at the Koto cooking school - a great initiative the NZ community in Viet Nam is right behind.
Pleasure to meet once again with Viet Nam Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung after his visit to NZ earlier this year.
Today I laid a wreath at Viet Nam’s Monument for National Heroes and at the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum.
There’s just a few more days to apply for the Pacific Youth Awards, a unique opportunity to celebrate the achievements of young Pacific New Zealanders. Find out more at pacificyouthawards.org.nz
Visited Silverdale School this morning with local MP Mark Mitchell MP to pick up our buddies for Buddy Day.
Enjoyed visiting the Canterbury A&P show and meeting the current – and next – generation of farmers.
Got a first-hand look at Christchurch’s new Margaret Mahy children’s playground with local MPs Gerry Brownlee and Nicky Wagner.

I'm looking forward to travelling to Southeast Asia later this week to build on our important economic, security and political links with the region.
Enjoyed having students from Mahurangi College in Warkworth pop in for a chat while they’re visiting Parliament.

Seven years ago today, the 8th of November 2008, the fifth National Government was elected by New Zealanders. Since then we've overcome the Global Financial Crisis, met the challenge of the Canterbury earthquakes and supported the rebuild, became the first Government to raise benefits in 43 years, put the Kermadecs into an ocean sanctuary, got the Government's books back into order, and ended the brain drain to Australia, just to name a few achievements! It remains a privilege to be Prime Minister, and I promise that we will continue to work hard to build a brighter future for all New Zealanders.
https://www.national.org.nz/news/features/seven-years-on-national-continues-to-deliver-for-new-zealanders
Visited Southwell School in Hamilton following an invitation from their talented student Jack Austin.
Good luck to all of the 145,000 students who start sitting their NCEA exams from tomorrow. You've worked hard, now it's time to demonstrate what a great year you've had in 2015.
Exciting to launch New Zealand’s Great Walks on Google Maps, a great tourism partnership between Google, Air New Zealand, and the Department of Conservation.
I've just got back from an enjoyable trip to Brussels, Marrakech and London, which included taking a significant step towards a free trade agreement with the EU.
Back-to-back Rugby World Cups, what an incredible game by the All Blacks! Absolute legends!
Good luck to the All Blacks in a few hours time. There's a stadium of 4.6m Kiwis backing you all the way.
Popped in to the Sky TV studio here in London to record a good luck message for the All Blacks ahead of tomorrow's game.

Honoured to lay a wreath at Tyne Cot Cemetery in Belgium - the largest Commonwealth war cemetery in the world - where the sacrifice of 1,696 New Zealanders who died at the battles of Broodseinde and Passchendaele is memorialised.
Thrilled to join Jonah Lomu for dinner on his Unstoppable tour tonight in London.
It was a pleasure to meet Morocco's Prime Minister Abdelilah Benkirane today in Rabat and to join him and some of his Cabinet colleagues for dinner.
Congratulations to Bill English and Nick Smith on 25 years in Parliament today. You’re dedicated and passionate MPs and Ministers, and it’s a privilege to work alongside you.
Met the hardworking team at Fitzroy Engineering with Local MP Jonathan Young today.
Visited the stunning new Len Lye Centre in New Plymouth this morning.
Called Canada’s new Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to offer my congratulations.
I’ve arrived in Malta for CHOGM. Many of our key trading partners are Commonwealth countries, so it’s a chance to talk trade.

Nick Smith and I have just been updated on the next stage of the Hobsonville Point home development, the Buckley B precinct, which will see 1000 new houses being developed two years ahead of schedule in response to high demand.

I'm just back from a productive trip to Viet Nam, then to APEC in the Philippines, and the East Asia Summit in Malaysia. Trips like these over a long period of time have delivered real benefits to New Zealand and helped us build friendships across the region. And there's more to come as I fly out on Wednesday to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Malta, a climate change summit in Paris and visit German Chancellor Angela Merkel in Berlin.
Regional security and economic issues were on the agenda at the 10th East Asia Summit in Kuala Lumpur today.
Arrived in Kuala Lumpur yesterday and toured the baggage handling system at KL International Airport - run by NZ company BCS.
Pleasure to open New Zealand's Chancery in Manila. Our staff here are doing a great job building our ties with the Philippines.
Today leaders of the APEC member countries are meeting to discuss issues including economic growth and shared prosperity.
Just touched down in Manila for the APEC Leaders' Meeting.  The focus will be on regional trade cooperation, including the TPP.
Today the NZ delegation and I met with representatives of Viet Nam's Vingroup to discuss how they can expand cooperation with New Zealand businesses.
Our hearts go out to the victims of today's attacks in Paris and our thoughts are with them and their families.
Opened the new premises of Biomarine in Warkworth, a company that exports roughly 3.6 million oysters from Northland to the world.
Thankfully it was free entry for my Buddy Day buddy “Jackson Seth Danger” at the Northern Arena in Silverdale. He wasn’t so keen on joining in the morning swim class though.
Proud to support Paralympics New Zealand's fundraising dinner last night as they get ready to head to Rio de Janeiro next year. #SpiritOfGold
An honour to help turn the first sod for the Christchurch Earthquake Memorial.

More good news for tourism and regional New Zealand, with Air New Zealand announcing they’re purchasing additional ATR72-600s to grow their regional routes.
An absolute privilege for Bronagh and I to welcome Their Royal Highnesses The Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall to Wellington today.
My money is on Hartnell, Preferment and Trip to Paris for the Melbourne Cup. Who are you backing? Good luck to all the competitors.
Great to catch up with David Cameron for dinner last night. Especially enjoyed the Halloween inspired ghost meringues made by his daughter Nancy.

What a game! Springboks pushed the All Blacks hard but what an outstanding response.

Tune in from 11.15am to my first ever Google Hangout with New Zealand secondary schools.
Thanks to the success of the Government's economic plan to create sustainable growth, New Zealand is one of the first OECD countries to return to surplus following the Global Financial Crisis.
Fantastic to see our tourism sector going from strength to strength.
Officially opened Cholmondeley Children’s Centre on a glorious Christchurch day.
Met the good folk at Mitre 10 on Ferry Rd in Christchurch today where the flag debate is flying high.
I’ve spent the past few days visiting our troops at Camp Taji, who are doing an amazing job in tough conditions to train Iraq’s soldiers to meet the threat posed by ISIL.
New Zealand exported $28 billion in goods and services to our new TPP partners in 2014, which is around 40 per cent of New Zealand’s overall exports.

TPP is made up of 12 countries in the Asia-Pacific region, which together account for 36 per cent of the world economy. It eliminates tariffs on 93 per cent of New Zealand's exports to the United States, Japan, Canada, Mexico and Peru.
TPP is a very positive agreement for New Zealand, improving access to international markets and supporting Kiwi exporters to grow and create new jobs.
It may not be the big screen but whatever it takes to catch the All Blacks when you're travelling right?
Met with other Pacific leaders and UN Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon at the UN today to discuss Pacific regional issues.
Catching up with New York-based NZ businesses, their customers and a few ex-pats too – all doing great things here.
Fantastic to experience one of the great sports rivalries - watching the New York Yankees play the Boston Red Sox.
Visiting Air New Zealand's Pleased to Seat You tour in New York City. Great to see more direct links between NZ and the USA making it easier for even more people to come visit us.

Proud to announce a 620,000 km2 Kermadec Ocean Sanctuary at the United Nations this morning. This sanctuary will be twice the size of New Zealand. The Kermadecs is a world-class, unspoiled marine environment and New Zealand will now protect it for future generations.
Quick catch-up with President Barack Obama after his speech to the UN General Assembly.

The Kermadec Ocean Sanctuary will be one of the world’s largest and most significant fully-protected areas, preserving important habitats for seabirds, whales and dolphins, endangered marine turtles and thousands of species of fish and other marine life. It will cover 15 per cent of New Zealand’s Exclusive Economic Zone, an area twice the size of our landmass, and 50 times the size of our largest national park in Fiordland.
I’ve just announced the creation of a 620,000 km2 Ocean Sanctuary in the Kermadec region, one of the most pristine and unique environments on Earth.
Great afternoon tea to celebrate the achievements of our Special Olympics team.
