Post-Cabinet press conference 22 February

As part of his Napier visit, John stopped off to officially launch the Bikes in Schools programme at St Mary's in Hastings. He was hosted by St Mary's principal Liz Crowley, Craig Foss, MP for Tukituki, and Chris Tremain, MP for Napier. He was joined at the ribbon cutting (and on the cross country training track) by BMX world champion Sarah Walker. The programme is primarily a project underwritten by Paul and Meg McArdle of “Bike On” which provided sixty quality bikes and helmets to the school.

This group of pictures was taken during a walk from the festitval's launch event and the town's ampitheatre where bands played on well into the wee hours. Lots of families, lots of costumes, lots of fun for everyone! John was hosted by Tukituki MP Craig Foss and Napier MP (and Government Whip) Chris Tremain.

I wanted to let you know that I really appreciate your comments on our new broadband policy announcement. Thousands of you had a look at the video and hundreds of you have used one channel or another to express your thoughts about the initiative. 

I'm happy to say that, overwhelmingly, your responses have been positive.  A number of you have also raised concerns about alternative technologies, data caps and the scarcity of international bandwidth, all things we are taking under advisement.  

So keep your ideas and comments coming - we're listening, and thinking, about what you say.

On Saturday, 17 January, Prime Minister John Key broke his arm in two places in a fall at an event in Auckland. During a trip to Papua New Guinea for the Pacific Forum Leaders' meeting and a subsequent stopover in the Solomon Islands, his cast was signed by a number of international dignitaries, including Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd. Now that signed cast - which will come off in the next two weeks - is available to bidders on TradeMe. The beneficiary of the winning bid will be The Fred Hollows Foundation NZ, which operates blindness prevention programmes in the Pacific. The Foundation estimates there are 5,000 blind people in the Solomon Islands, mainly needing cataract surgery. A further 15,000 will be suffering from poor vision from cataracts and the need for glasses. Five eye doctors and 20 eye nurses are required to address blindness and vision disability in the Solomon Islands. There are currently two eye doctors and 12 eye nurses working in the Solomon Islands. John Key will also sign the cast and - subject to scheduling arrangements - will meet with the winning bidder for morning tea.

According to NewstalkZB today, there has been a 35 percent increase in the number of New Zealanders living overseas who are enrolled to vote in election 2008. 

"Nearly 48,000 New Zealanders living overseas are enrolled to vote in the this year's election, a 35 per cent increase on 2005. 

"Electoral Enrolment Centre national manager Murray Wicks says it is partly due to more New Zealanders moving overseas and travelling. 

"But he says it is also because people can now easily access enrolment information online and download their voting papers."

If you're living overseas, join our group http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=9110653029 for New Zealanders who will be voting from offshore.

On KiwiFM - The referendum, student loans and KiwiSaver

25 June. John talks with KiwiFM presenter Wammo about the 'smacking' referendum. Wammo fronts a number of objections to the referendum, including a contention that many of the signers of the petition calling for the referendum did so out of ignorance about the law.  John explains that the real issue is democracy in action - and that the attempt by the Government to postpone the referendum until after the General Election is an act of arrogance.  John and Wammo then talk about National's positions on student loans and KiwiSaver.

Statement from John Carter   

National Party Northland MP John Carter says he deeply regrets an incident between himself and a police officer who stopped him for a driving offence. 

"I have offered a full and unreserved apology to the Northland police via their district commander. I am disappointed with my own conduct. 

"My behaviour was not appropriate for an MP and I am sorry. I have immense respect for the job that the police do."
